snippet: The federal judge overseeing Eastman Kodak's bankruptcy case ruled on Monday that the company could proceed with a sale of its digital imaging patents, a crucial part of its reorganization efforts.
abstract: The federal judge overseeing Eastman Kodak's bankruptcy case ruled on Monday that the company could proceed with a sale of its digital imaging patents, a crucial part of its reorganization efforts.

headline.main: Judge Lets Kodak Patent Auction Move Forward

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday's selection includes an explanation of how YouTube counts views and a story of a freelance programmer who sneaked into Apple for week...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Monday's selection includes an explanation of how YouTube counts views and a story of a freelance programmer who sneaked into Apple for weeks after his project was canceled so he could finish the job.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: YouTube 301 and Apple Obsession

snippet: Google’s proposal seeks to address European concerns that it might have abused its dominance in Internet search by promoting its own businesses at the expense of rivals.
abstract: Google sends a proposal to the European Commission seeking to address concerns that it might have abused its dominance in Internet search by promoting its own businesses at the expense of rivals; faces prospect of formal antitrust charges.

headline.main: To Avoid a Long Dispute, Google Offers to Settle a European Antitrust Case
headline.print_headline: To Avoid a Long Dispute, Google Offers to Settle a European Antitrust Case

snippet: Twitter has warned developers that they should not build apps on the company's platform, citing the need for "consistency," but it's apparent that Twitter-built products are anything but consistent.
abstract: Twitter has warned developers that they should not build apps on the company's platform, citing the need for "consistency," but it's apparent that Twitter-built products are anything but consistent.

snippet: A Chinese provincial court said the American technology company had settled a lawsuit by paying $60 million into a court-approved bank account for the legal rights to use the iPad trademark in China.

headline.main: Apple Settles iPad Trademark Dispute With Chinese Company
headline.print_headline: Apple Settles iPad Trademark Dispute With Chinese Company

snippet: A Chinese provincial court said on Monday that Apple had settled a lawsuit there by agreeing to pay $60 million for the legal rights to use the iPad trademark in China.
abstract: Apple agrees to pay $60 million for the legal rights to use the iPad trademark in China, settling a long-running trademark dispute with Chinese company Proview Technology of Taiwan.

headline.main: Apple Settles an iPad Dispute in China
headline.print_headline: Apple Settles an iPad Dispute in China
